Name: Review of biofuels research and policy
Agriculture and CBD
Memo: Traditionally oversight of land management for agricultural production and biodiversity conservation has been undertaken by separate bodies at international, national and local scales. This project aims to review the CBD approach to agricultural biodiversity in the context of an ecosystem approach. UNEP-WCMC will work with the CBD Secretariat and other key stakeholders at the national level to investigate whether the current separation into a standalone programme of work on agricultural biodiversity constrains the mainstreaming of biodiversity across the work of the convention at national and international levels, and, if it does, identify options for addressing any concerns raised.

Name: Traditional Knowledge Frameworks
Memo: This project aims to develop guidance on how to incorporate traditional knowledge which can be implemented by assessment practitioners carrying out ecosystem assessments at different scales

Name: New database on National Biodiversity

Name: IHS 2011 - 2013

Name: IUCN World Heritage Gap Analysis
Memo: Prepare in consultation with IUCN a costed proposal for updating and publishing in a proper printed format (in both English and French) the global gap analysis prepared by Magin and Chape in 2004. The publication will include improved use of maps. The updated analysis should focus on a data-driven quantitative analysis and cover criteria (ix) and (x) for both terrestrial and freshwater environments, reference relevant previous theme studies (e.g. on biodiversity, forests, mountains and wetlands), and with a target date in time for the 35th session of the Committee in June/July 2011. The proposal should outline the rationale, scope, inputs, outputs, partners, process and its coordination, timing and cost of the analysis, and be submitted electronically to IUCN by 30 June 2010.

Name: On-demand technical support to PEI count
Memo: The UNDP-UNEP Poverty and Environment Initiative (PEI) support countries conducting ecosystem assessments for the purpose of poverty-environment mainstreaming. PEI and WCMC will jointly define a modality for PEI to access technical expertise from UNEP-WCMC in the field of integrated ecosystem assessments, valuation of ecosystem goods and services and indicator development, in particular when PEI carries out country level studies. Such help would be needed for example for (on demand) reviews of draft terms of reference or requests for proposals, identifying or accessing experts and peer-reviewing the reports / outputs from the countries. PEI will shortly start a rapid assessment / valuation in Burkina Faso (the terms of reference are under development) which PEI and WCMC will trial under this modality.

Name: Collaboration with IIED
Memo: Senior staff from UNEP-WCMC and IIED meet on Monday 11 October to explore the possibility for establishing a formal collaboration between the two organisations. The meeting identified complementary areas of strength and interest that will help both organisations to achieve their mandates by coherently tackling important trends in the biodiversity and development landscape. The key outcome was identification of 3 areas of mutual interest to explore: (1) Evidence Base for Poverty-Biodiversity Linkages (WCMC contact: MATT), (2) Reciprocal Mainstreaming of Biodiversity and Development (WCMC contact: JESSICA), (3), Big Trends: Seeing the Future of Land Use (WCMC contact: JON H/ALISON). UNEP-WCMC and IIED will follow-up to flesh out relevant concept notes, identify suitable donors, and the modality of collaboration over the coming months.

Name: MPA EU Overseas
Memo:
Contact is Dominique Benzaken - purpose of project is to do assessments of MPAs in overseease territories, in terms of network characteristics and impacts on resilience to climate change impacts. Based on discussions on 18th April 2011, primary activities would include
- delineate 'regions' that capture the EU OS Territories based on existing biogeographic / political boundaries
- update MPA data for all EU overseas territories
- analysis of network characteristcis of MPAs (using similar methodology as in Wood et al Oryx paper); do this for regions, including OS territories only and then including non-OS territories countries that are included in the broad region
- within 1 region (possibly WIO), collate data on area-based measures and re-do network analysis including those areas (again including / excluding non-OS territories)
- interpret in terms of a) need for holistic marine spatial planning approach to fully understand management approaches to OS territories and b) need for regional integration with non-OS territory countires that are nearby

Name: Indicators for impacts of REDD on biodiv
Support for an Environmental and Social
Memo: The Naftogaz Master Plan envisages an investment of $3bn for rehabilitation and modernisation of the Ukraine Gas Transit System.  It is requirement of the financing of this rehabilitation and modernization that Environmental and Social Assessments be carried out.  These assessments should be carried out by Naftogaz of Ukraine with support from an experienced consultant.  As part of Nippon Koei’s bid to be engaged as the consultant in this project, you require support from an organization with data and expertise to support mapping and biodiversity analysis along pipeline routes and at gas storage locations.  As custodian of several key biodiversity datasets, and through the significant biodiversity expertise of our staff, UNEP-WCMC is ideally positioned to support Nippon Koei UK in this project.

Name: Mapping Threats in New Priority Areas
Memo:
For three of the MacArthur Foundation’s new focus areas this project will:
 
 
 
1.       Provide analyses and priorities to inform the development of the MacArthur Foundation’s new strategy for 2011-2020, 
2.       Provide a baseline to help assess the impacts of the MacArthur Foundation’s strategy.
 
 
The project aims to support the implementation of the Foundation’s strategy, and in particular, the fourth objective: Build capacity to respond to global drivers of ecosystem decline and specifically the components: i) Integrated environmental/social considerations into commodity markets and ii) Understand and mitigate China’s natural resource use in Asia, Africa and LAC.

Name: Mapping Threats in New Priority Areas
WWF sustainable biomass
Memo: WWF Germany has secured a 3-year IKI project on sustainable biomass production and they have expressed interest in involving us in some of the project’s components. The project started in March 2009; when exactly our involvement will start is yet unclear. We are hoping for a budget of around 30K € for stafftime

Name: Zambia: Mapping the multiple benefits
Memo: This project would map the potential for multiple benefits from REDD+ in Zambia, i.e. national forest biodiversity and ecosystem services, and their spatial relationship to carbon stocks. This activity would fulfill part of Zambia’s National Programme for REDD+, and would be undertaken in full collaboration with appropriate counterparts in Zambia, including through a spatial analysis workshop.

Name: Mountain Protected Area Gap Analysis
Memo:
1. To identify mountain areas of global significance for biodiversity conservation that are currently unprotected
 
 
 
2. As a subset of (1),( and subject to an available budget), to identify (all) mountain areas with globally exceptional biodiversity values which may meet World Heritage criteria (ix) and (x)
 
 
3. To use the analysis [and a subsequent IUCNM WCPA peer review assessment] as part of a future collegiate conservation priority setting project for mountains with the Mountains Partnership

Name: Evidence for EBA (CCI)
Memo: Ecosystem-based approaches to adaptation (EBA) has been suggested as an integral way to help people adapt to climate change. Although there exist some cases studies with regards to the implementation of EBA, there has been no systematic study to review the evidence as to the effectiveness of EBA. This study will therefore examine the existing evidence of the effectiveness of EBA through a review of cases that are either explicitly for climate change adaptation or use practices that increase ecosystem resilience and sustain people’s livelihoods.

Name: Integrated approaches to ecosystem
Memo: Develop a global framework for quantifying the ecosystem service impacts of oil and biofuel production. This would involve, developing an methodology of assessing impacts of fossil fuels and biofuels on ecosystem services, and a case study using the IHS Energy dataset to assess the impacts of fossil fuel production and other data to assess biofuel plantations and processing impacts. This is a collaborative project with the University of Southampton and Imperial College.

Indicatively, the database will be equipped with a back-office platform for content management, a front-end platform for dissemination of information, an email notification system, advanced search engine functionalities, and a data mining tool for statistical analysis and charting (i.e. Dashboard).

Name: Biodiversity impacts of GM crops
Memo: This project will compile information and develop tools to assist policy makers in comparing the benefits and costs to biodiversity of using crop varieties developed through either conventional breeding techniques or genetic engineering technology. The project will deliver a transparent comparison of the biodiversity impacts of the different methods of crop development by undertaking a systematic review of evidence; and spatial mapping of the biodiversity impacts, both positive and negative, of the use of genetically engineered (GE) and other crops.

Google Support to Improve WDPA Metadata
Memo: This project will supply the WDPA to Google for incorporation into Google Maps, Earth and other Google products.  It will involve a combination of system upgrades to cope with extra traffic and tightening agreements from data providers.

Immediate priorities are: IPBES capacity building; NBSAPs technical support programme; Resilience, possible UNDP-Stockholm Resilience-WCMC joint approach ensuring socio-economic dimension, e.g., roll-out of Mauritius project approach; and Other, e.g., projects in Russia, Nigeria, Guaina Shield, etc [leads from Jon].

Memo: Objective: Review progress toward the achievement of the CBD’s 2020 protected area targets and communicate key facts about the status and trends in the global protection of biodiversity and ecosystem services to decision makers.

Name: Operationalising ecosystem service conce
Memo:
Details:
 
 
 
We have been asked by Marc Metzger at Edinburgh University to join a consortium bid for a EC Framework 7 call for proposals. Marc is sending an outline in coming days and there will be a planning meeting late August in Brussels. Details of the EU call as follows:
 
 
 
ENV.2012.6.2-1 Exploration of the operational potential of the concepts of ecosystem services and natural capital to systematically inform sustainable land, water and urban management 
Ecosystem services and natural capital are increasingly put forward as key conceptual approaches to improve land-use management and develop innovative public goods and sustainable economic activities. This requires a better understanding of (i) the potential of the ecosystem services and natural capital approach and (ii) how best to operationalise these concepts within key regulatory frameworks. Integrated natural, social and economic research is needed to assess the ecosystem services relevant to human well-being, and analyse links between and comparisons across locales, sectors, scales and time (for example, across a network of coherent case studies) in a range of social-ecological systems, including fresh water bodies and rural and urban areas. Focusing on the biological/physical control of ecosystem services, research will examine the effects of multiple drivers, structural factors (including biodiversity), and human feedbacks on ecosystem services. Such research is to (i) provide a better understanding of how drivers and management, including the green infrastructure approach, change ecosystem services, and (ii) explore, demonstrate and validate mechanisms, instruments and best practices that will serve to maintain and enhance a sustainable flow of a broad range of services from ecosystems while preserving their ecological value and biological diversity. Focusing on the socio-economic implications of choices on the use of ecosystem services, research will address the trade-offs and synergies between ecosystem services and between components of social and individual well-being that arise from the demands on these systems. Such research is to (iii) qualify and quantify these trade-offs and synergies and link them to the respective stakeholders across locales, sectors, scales and time, (iv) identify the potential for the development of innovative and sustainable processes derived from ecosystem services, and (v) explore, demonstrate and validate instruments and practices that will serve to align disconnected and conflicting interests and take power asymmetries into account in balancing trade-offs in social and individual well-being. In both biological/physical and socio-economic dimensions, work will (vi) develop methods and coherent and shared protocols to provide consistent and integrated datasets and knowledge (vii) and explore and where possible implement ways to ensure the perennity of any key data base, decision support system or other major product of the research. Integrating these strands of investigation, research is to provide plural and conditional alternatives for operationalising the concept of ecosystem services and natural capital to support the formulation and implementation of regulatory frameworks such as the Water Framework Directive, the Common Agricultural Policy, the Green Infrastructure approach, the Thematic Strategy on the Urban Environment and Environmental Impact Assessments.

Name: Kenyan protected area complementarity
Memo: AFD have released a research tender to develop an analytical framework to explore complementarity and efficiency amongst state, private and community-based protected areas, and to test its application in a Kenya  context. We are applying as part of a partnership with IIED and the African Wildlife Foundation in Kenya. Our role with IIED will be planning  and oversight of international elements especially literature review and framework development.

Name: Ecosystem services, MPAs and EU OTs
CCAD
Memo: An analysis of CCAD  countries’ Annual Reports to CITES is proposed, to support the region’s effective implementation of the Convention. This analysis would take the form of a confidential, scientifically rigorous report, to provide CCAD members with a regional perspective concerning CITES  trade. The report would provide a solid platform to support decision-making processes in the region, assist in the identification of common needs and opportunities, and help to ensure that CITES is being effectively implemented. This proposal builds on the successful experience of similar analyses carried out on a regular basis by UNEP-WCMC for other countries and regions, such as the European Union.

Name: Developing capacity in Turkmenistan
Memo: This project aims to establish an inventory of wetlands for Turkmenistan, with a particular focus on establishing the baseline understanding of ecosystem services provided by wetlands and their value.

Name: Reindeer Calving Grounds
Comp Prog Name: UNEP-WCMC Business, Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services

Name: EU Wise Marine 2012
Memo:
The overall aim of this project is to provide support to the European Commission for the further development of the reporting system for the Marine Strategy Framework Directive (MSFD) through the marine component of the Water Information System for Europe (WISE-Marine). This will involve: further development and refinement of the reporting sheets for MFSD Articles 8, 9 and 10 that are currently under development; consideration of existing data reported under the MSFD; potential synergies with other Directives and regional and international Conventions; and the development of reporting summaries to compare, aggregate, summarise and visualise the information and data that will be held in WISE-Marine. 
The project has three main components according to these requirements:
• Initiation of the development of ‘output content’ from the data and information reported by Member States under the MSFD in 2012;
• Review of links between MSFD reporting requirements and reporting under other EU Directives (e.g. Habitats and Birds Directives, Water Framework Directive) and international agreements such as the Regional Sea Conventions (RSCs);
• Refinement of reporting sheets for Articles 8, 9 and 10, and development of reporting sheets for Article 11 (Monitoring requirements).
The project will involve close interaction with the European Commission (EC), European Environment Agency (EEA), Member States and the Working Group on Data, Information and Knowledge Exchange (WG DIKE) to ensure that developments are in line with Commission, EEA and Member State requirements. The project will take place over one year, potentially renewable for a further year.
MRAG Ltd, in association with URS Scott-Wilson and UNEP-WCMC, are currently developing the reporting sheets for Articles 8, 9 and 10 of the MSFD and are well placed to continue this work and provide the further inputs and analysis required to assess links with other directives and agreements, and develop output content for WISE-Marine.

Name: Defra NBSAPS
Memo: The aim of this project is to identifiy the lessons learnt for mainstraining economic value of biodiversity and ecosystem services into National Biodiversity and Action Stratgies (NBSAPs), planning processes, poverty reduction stratgies and national accounts. This project will draw on a number of different initiatives such as the national TEEB/TEEB-related studies and the TEEB network, CBD Secretariat led NBSAP revision workshops, ecosystem assessments and the sub-global assessment network.

Name: Monitoring Protected Areas
Memo: Through a wide range of consultations and a small expert workshop, this project aims to develop an updated set of guidelines for monitoring protected areas which can be utilized in protected area sites and networks of sites.

Name: Proteus 2013 - 2015
Comp Prog Name: UNEP-WCMC Business, Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services

Name: IFAD small holder agriculture report
Memo: IFAD and UNEP are seeking a partner to manage the research and coordination of a seminal paper on the role of smallholders, food security and sustainable agriculture ‘for the future we want.’  The partner may potentially work with and manage a consortium of partners, would undertake a review of existing research, be responsible for the intellectual rigor, proper sourcing and graphic representations of the content, and work directly with IFAD and UNEP throughout the research, drafting and finalization process.

Name: Integrated Conservation of Ancient Plant
Memo:
This project seeks to enhance the global conservation of threatened cycads  through the integration of innovative in situ and ex situ approaches and knowledge transfer  between Thailand, China, South Africa and Mexico. Work undertaken through the project could feed into CITES processes in the partner countries and the wider CITES arena, for instance by collecting information relevant to the making of non-detriment findings, by reviewing legislation pertaining to the harvest and trade of cycads, by analysing trade data and providing guidance on sustainable harvest levels and best practice – UNEP-WCMC will contribute to these aspects of the project. There are also a number of CBD programmes of work and initiatives this project could potentially contribute to. 
Jon Hutton will contribute to twice yearly board meetings (expenses to be covered) and UNEP-WCMC will contribute to 1 annual workshop over 3 years (stafftime 2500 + travel expenses).

Name: Revision of the reporting tools -Phase 3
Memo: Review of templates and guidelines for reporting on UNCCD impact indicators (prepared in 6060.00 - phase 1) with feedback received through country piloting (6060.01 – phase 2) and through the UNCCD Conference of the Parties in October 2011. Support external review and translation in time for products to be used by all Parties to the Convention from early 2012.

Name: Pacific Coral Disease ID
Memo: In collaboration with the Living Oceans Foundation, UNEP-WCMC will support the development of a field guide to improve the identification of coral diseases and other causes of mortality in the Pacific which will support researchers and managers in the Pacific region to accurately define and record coral diseases using standardised nomenclature, and contribute to the global understanding of coral disease.

Name: UN-REDD Phase II
Memo: Support to the UN-REDD Programme on multiple benefits. Funded by DEPI from its Global Programme funds. Includes tools, guidance, development of environmental principles and criteria for REDD+.

Name: EUROGEOSS (salary costs)
Memo: European Commission FP7 funded project which aims to improve the mechanisms for integrating data and tools across sectors relating to biodiversity, forestry and drought. The biodiversity component of the project will improve interoperability between GBIF, Birdlife, UNEP-WCMC and RSPB data.

Name: High Seas Information module
Memo: UNEP-WCMC is undertaking this project to implement the Convention on Biological Diversity’s COP decision IX/20, paragraph 5, regarding access to and use of information about marine areas beyond the limits of national jurisdiction.  The project delivers development of an online, interactive map and decision-support tool, called the High Seas Viewer, which is intended to support science and policy communities by providing information on marine areas beyond national jurisdiction, incorporating information on ecosystem functions, connectivity, threats and habitats in the water column.  In collaboration with partners including the Marine Geospatial Ecology Lab at Duke University, this project aims to link with other relevant organizations and activities including the International Maritime Organization, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, the Global Ocean Biodiversity Initiative and the World Database on Protected Areas.

Name: IUCN Chair SSC - Al Ain Funds
CI Funds to IUCN SSC Chair
National Ecosystem Assessment
Memo: The UK National Ecosystem Assessment (UK NEA) is the first analysis of the UK’s natural environment in terms of the benefits it provides to society and our continuing prosperity. Part of the Living With Environmental Change (LWEC) initiative, the assessment began in mid-2009 and will be reporting its findings in early 2011. It is an inclusive process involving individuals and institutions with a wide range of perspectives, in government, academia, NGOs and the private sector, following the process embodied in the Millennium Assessment. UNEP-WCMC has been contracted by DEFRA (and the devolved administrations) to act as the secretariat and to co-ordinate the UK NEA.

Name: National Ecosystem Assessment (INCOME)
Memo: The UK National Ecosystem Assessment (UK NEA) is the first analysis of the UK’s natural environment in terms of the benefits it provides to society and our continuing prosperity. Part of the Living With Environmental Change (LWEC) initiative, the assessment began in mid-2009 and will be reporting its findings in early 2011. It is an inclusive process involving individuals and institutions with a wide range of perspectives, in government, academia, NGOs and the private sector, following the process embodied in the Millennium Assessment. UNEP-WCMC has been contracted by DEFRA (and the devolved administrations) to act as the secretariat and to co-ordinate the UK NEA.

Name: Climate Change Programme Activities
Memo: The purpose of this project is to provide small levels of support to activities of the Climate Change and Biodiversity Programme that are not funded by other projects. Is this really externally funded?

Name: UK Permit Exchange
Memo: Pilot procedures that will allow information necessary for the production of CITES import/export/re-export permits and certificates to pass between the Swiss and UK management authorities in an electronic format.

Name: HERMIONE Consortium
Memo: Hermione is an EC co-funded project on Hotspot Ecosystem Research and Man’s Impact on European Seas. It has the following main objectives: to investigate the dimensions, distribution and interconnection of deep-sea ecosystems; to understand changes in deep-sea ecosystems related to key factors including climate change, human impacts and the impacy of large scale episodic events; to understand the biological capacities and specific adaptations of deep sea organisms and investigate the importance of biodiversity in the functioning of deep-water ecosystems; and to provide stakeholders and policy makers with scientific knowledge to support deep=sea governance aimed at the sustainable management and the conservation of ecosystems. UNEP-WCMC's role is spread across all work packages, to support the science policy interface aspects of the project. It also has more substantial time allocated to working on socio-economics and governance issues related to the deep sea, including the use of criteria to identify potential areas for protection / increased management (e.g. FAO's criteria to identify Vulnerable Marine Ecosystems & the CBD's criteria to identify Ecologically and Biologically Significant Areas on the open ocean and deep seas).

Name: CSI CAFTA-DR2
Memo: CSI Central America is as above yet with an additional three components. This project is also developing products that enhance the support framework for CSI practitioners once trained. These include an online alumni network, a 20 minute documentary for raising awareness of the programme and encouraging government support for CSI teams post training, a review of the CSI programme following three years of operation, and providing assistance to our Dominican Republic partner in hosting a meeting with relevant government departments about institutuionalising the CSI response team.

Name: EU Wildlife Trade 2012-2013
Memo: Assist the EC with the smooth and effective implementation of Council Regulation (EC) No 338/97 and the Implementing Regulation and the Suspension Regulation which together provide the basis for EU's controls on import and export of wildlife and wildlife products. Project to run 2011-2013.

Name: Great Green Wall Initiative
Memo:
Wealth in Drylands: A policy-oriented assessment for sustainable livelihood options in dry and sub-humid areas
 
 
Incomplete knowledge about drylands potential can prevent policy makers at all levels from taking the necessary measures to encourage sustainable development and livelihoods in dry and sub-humid areas. This proposal puts forward the need for a policy-oriented assessment which encourages and informs thinking about the potential wealth from drylands. An enhanced evidence base and policy tools developed will support improved drylands planning and development with due regard to conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity.

Name: Great Green Wall Initiative
Memo:
Wealth in Drylands: A policy-oriented assessment for sustainable livelihood options in dry and sub-humid areas
 
 
Incomplete knowledge about drylands potential can prevent policy makers at all levels from taking the necessary measures to encourage sustainable development and livelihoods in dry and sub-humid areas. This proposal puts forward the need for a policy-oriented assessment which encourages and informs thinking about the potential wealth from drylands. An enhanced evidence base and policy tools developed will support improved drylands planning and development with due regard to conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity.

Name: A-Z guidance to business - EIB INCOME
Comp Prog Name: UNEP-WCMC Business, Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services

Name: A-Z guidance to business
Memo: Several mechanisms currently exist to identify and protect areas of global and national significance for biodiversity. Keeping track of the different systems, their criteria for designation, legal status, their implications for companies’ activities, etc. is often challenging for all sectors.  Some of these mechanisms are based on national legal frameworks or recognition through international conventions and programmes, while other areas are supported or recognized by the academic and conservation communities. While all of these areas hold importance for biodiversity there is often a need for better understanding of the different criteria and the sensitivity of such areas, the objectives behind their designation and the legal restrictions of relevance to commercial operations. In order to address this need, this study will provide an overview of the commonly used systems to prioritize and protect areas of biodiversity importance and discuss the implications for companies operating in or near such areas in terms of the severity of potential impacts, opportunities for delivering benefits and legal ramifications.
Comp Prog Name: UNEP-WCMC Business, Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services

Some of these mechanisms are based on national legal frameworks or recognition through international conventions and programmes, while other areas are supported or recognized by the academic and conservation communities. Name: Biodiversity offsets Whitepaper
Comp Prog Name: UNEP-WCMC Business, Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services

Name: Reducing emissions from deforestation
Memo: The project  will compare several alternative approaches to emission reduction calculation in REDD using data collected from remotely sensed images and field studies at forest sites in Sierra Leone and Sumatra, where the RSPB is involved in conservation work. We will develop and test alternative predictive models, evaluate their effectiveness and produce a report for incorporation into the GOFC-GOLD sourcebook – the authoritative source of scientific information for REDD policy makers.

Name: UNCCD PRAIS
Memo: UNEP-WCMC is executing a full-size ($2.8M plus $5M co-financing) GEF project in support of the UN Convention to Combat Desertificaiton (UNCCD). The UNCCD Performance Review and Assessment of Implementation of the Strategy (PRAIS) Project will support all 192 Parties and other reporting entities to the Convention to undertake a scientifically rigorous and credible assessment of the performance of the implementation of the UNCCD at the national, sub-regional, regional and global levels. The project will work to strengthen capacity and knowledge management systems for subsequent assessments, including through an online reporting portal at 15 sub-regional technical Reference Centres established as knowledge hubs. In the long-term, the project will assist all stakeholders to identify priority areas for investment to enhance implementation of UNCCD, with the objective of improving the well-being of populations affected by Desertification, Land Degradation and Drought and the productivity of the ecosystems that they rely on.

Name: Co-financing to PRAIS
Memo: Repayment of funds advanced for RC SSFAs in 2010 from UNCCD’s EC grant, agreed by PRAIS project PSC.

Name: Global Atlas of Carbon Storage
Memo: Support countries in preparing and planning for climate change mitigation measures, including REDD, while simultaneously targeting ecosystem co-benefits, especially biodiversity. This project will produce a web-based carbon and biodiversity atlas and provide flexible tools based on maps and spatial analyses to assist countries to deliver benefits for biodiversity and ecosystem services from ecosystem-based climate mitigation policies, including REDD.

Name: Global Atlas of Carbon Storage-Extension
Memo: Support countries in preparing and planning for climate change mitigation measures, including REDD, while simultaneously targeting ecosystem co-benefits, especially biodiversity. This project will produce a web-based carbon and biodiversity atlas and provide flexible tools based on maps and spatial analyses to assist countries to deliver benefits for biodiversity and ecosystem services from ecosystem-based climate mitigation policies, including REDD.

Name: CCI Teaching Materials
Comp Prog Name: UNEP-WCMC Business, Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services

Name: Assessing Long Term Land Cover Change
Memo: The project will use higher resolution remote sensing data to track land-cover changes both inside and outside a large sample of sites of conservation importance in Africa. These analyses will be used to help assess how rates of change vary between protected areas and according to different levels of protection. In addition, the project aims to identify predictors of land-cover change within protected areas and Important Bird Area networks.

Name: FNR_Rio
Memo: The aim of this project is to pilot nationally-driven integrated processes and approaches to reporting to the three Rio Conventions (CBD, UNCCD and UNFCCC). The pilot countries are all LDCs (Afghanistan, Eritrea, Laos, Liberia) or SIDS (Mauritius and Palau), where capacity is relatively low and the need for increasing capacity by identifying potential synergies is high.

Name: IPBES Capacity Building
Memo: The aim of this project is to prepare a scoping paper for the Norwegian Government on ways in which they and others might respond to the capacity building needs arising from the IPBES process and discussions.

Name: ApesMapper
Memo: Decision makers interested in supporting conservation of Great Apes in the wild, including donors, need information to support their decision making processes, in order to ensure that actions are targeted appropriately, with the best possible long-term impact. UNEP-WCMC, the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology (MPI),  the SSC Great Ape Specialist Group, the Arcus Foundation and other organisations including the Jane Goodall Institute and UNEP-GRASP are developing an on-line interactive GIS system:"www.ApesMapper.org". This will provide a user friendly interface, enabling users to identify priority areas for conservation action. The second phase of the project will be completed by March 2012.

Name: ApesMapper (INCOME)
Memo: Decision makers interested in supporting conservation of Great Apes in the wild, including donors, need information to support their decision making processes, in order to ensure that actions are targeted appropriately, with the best possible long-term impact. UNEP-WCMC, the Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology (MPI),  the SSC Great Ape Specialist Group, the Arcus Foundation and other organisations including the Jane Goodall Institute and UNEP-GRASP are developing an on-line interactive GIS system:"www.ApesMapper.org". This will provide a user friendly interface, enabling users to identify priority areas for conservation action. The second phase of the project will be completed by March 2012.

Name: REDD Partnership VRD
Memo: Working together with FAO to establish and manage an online REDD+ financing, actions and results database (Voluntary REDD+ Database - VRD) in response to a call from the Oslo Climate and Forest Conference of over 50 countries, on 27 May 2010. The REDD+ Partnership agreement, produced at the conference, includes pledges to support REDD+ and transparency around its financing. The actions agreed include the design and maintenance of a database of REDD+ financing, actions and results, and provision of related analyses and reports.

Memo: To support UNEP-WCMC's efforts to expand the Integrated Biodiversity Assessment Tool and family of decision support systems targeting three key sectors: research and conservation planning, business, and development finance.

Name: EU Wise Marine
Memo:
The overall aim of the project is to assist the Commission with the development of Reporting Sheets for the reporting system of the Marine Strategy Framework Directive (MSFD, 2008/56/EC). The Reporting Sheets to be developed under this project are the conceptual models for specific reporting needs; they will specify what information needs to be reported, why it must be reported, and how it should be reported, detailing information requirements, formats, reporting frequencies and deadlines. Specifically, these Reporting Sheets will be developed for the reporting requirements under the MSFD that are due in 2012. 
 
 
Improving and streamlining the flow of data and information is important to help avoid duplication and reduce the burden of reporting on Member States. The MSFD information will be reported through WISE-Marine, the marine part of the Water Information System for Europe (WISE). The development of WISE-Marine is one step in the process of expanding WISE to incorporate various types of information.
 
 
 
The project will take place over one year and will progressively develop sets of Reporting Sheets for a selection of marine strategy elements due to be prepared in 2012 under the MSFD. The development of the Reporting Sheets will be based on a review of previously-developed Reporting Sheets for the Water Framework Directive (WFD), with which they will need to ensure coherence and compatibility. Their development will be carried out through an iterative process between the consultants and relevant institutions and Member States, in particular DG Environment and the Working Group on Data, Information and Knowledge Exchange (WG-DIKE). 
 
 
This process will be part of and will support the agreed Common Implementation Strategy for the MSFD, endorsed by the Marine Directors in May 2009.

Name: CCI soil carbon workshop
Memo: The aim of the project is to contribute to biodiversity conservation in agricultural and rangeland landscapes by investigating the potential for payments for soil carbon services (PSCS) to increase soil productivity, encourage above ground vegetation and support soil and other biodiversity.

Name: Database on cosmetic plants
Memo: Research literature relevant to six plant species identified by Chanel and review species fact-sheets produced by Label CBD to ensure that they meet the necessary standards to be included in a website on the sustainability of aromatic plant species used by the cosmetics industry.

Name: CBD pre-AHTEG indicator expert meeting
Memo: As Parties to the CBD consider the adoption of a revised, post-2010 Strategic Plan, there is a need to identify an appropriate framework of indicators with which to track and report progress towards the targets contained within the Strategic Plan, building on the existing framework adopted for reporting progress towards the 2010 target. UNEP-WCMC, together with the CBD Secretariat, proposes to convene an expert meeting to inform the proposed CBD Ad hoc Technical Expert Group on indicators.

Name: EMG 2011 work plan support
Memo:
In 2009 and 2010 UNEP-WCMC supported the Environment Management Group’s work to stimulate UN-wide cooperation and response on important land (4047) and biodiversity (4065) issues. The EMG Secretariat and UNEP-WCMC have had a productive working relationship, resulting in a number of high-profile outputs (see www.unemg.org) and enthusiasm generated for follow-on initiatives. The EMG Secretariat has requested UNEP-WCMC’s continued support on land and biodiversity, by for example, 
·         Supporting the Secretariat to ensure effective follow up to the findings of the report “Advancing the biodiversity agenda, A UN system wide Contribution” 
·         Assisting in responding to any requests made to the EMG from the UNGA high-level event on biodiversity, the 10th COP of the CBD and the preparatory process for the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development.
 
·         Finalizing and circulate for approval of the EMG members  the United Nations system-wide rapid response report on drylands, together with options for follow-up actions,
 
·         Assisting in preparing a joint agenda for action on drylands and possibly on land that would propose opportunities for cooperation and joint action on land
 
·         Supporting preparation of a report on the outcome of the above work to the 17th senior officials meeting (Sept 2011)
The EMG Secretariat and UNEP-WCMC are exploring whether this technical and coordination support relationship could expand to other issues on the EMG agenda, for example, Rio+20 preparation, Green Economy, International Environmental Governance, Social and environmental safeguards, and Sustainable management (inc climate neutrality, procurement). The proposed project consists of a comprehensive plan of action leading to the 17th Senior Officials meeting in late 2011.

Name: Rio Tinto – IUCN NPI
Comp Prog Name: UNEP-WCMC Business, Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services

Name: Indonesia REDD
Memo: Providing support to the Indonesian government in the implementation of several components of the National Joint Programme under UN-REDD. These include mapping of carbon and multiple benefits and the development of a toolkit to support decision-making on REDD+ activities at the provincial level.

Name: IPBES Expert Workshop (1)
Memo: The Norwegian and Brazilian Governments are co-hosting an international expert meeting to discuss opportunities for capacity building linked to operationalizing IPBES. This meeting will provide substantive input to the ongoing intergovernmental debate on the issues. UNEP-WCMC is working with the hosting governments to support them in preparing for and holding the meeting, and in preparing the resulting reports.

Name: BfN Ecosystem climate relevance
Memo: This project comprises development of a background study and organization of a workshop on the climate relevance of ecosystems other than forests and peatlands (e.g. savannas, tundras, steppes, seagrass beds), in order to inform future initiatives addressing the sustainable management of such ecosystems.

Name: Global Islands Phase 2
Memo: ToR need to change substantially given the delays in receiving the funds.

Name: GRI O&G
Comp Prog Name: UNEP-WCMC Business, Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services

Name: CBD Protected Planet Report
Memo: The Secretariat of the Convention on Biological Diversity (“the CBD Secretariat") and UNEP-WCMC agree to cooperate to measure and report progress made towards the CBD target for protected area coverage (Target 11 of the Aichi Biodiversity Targets). Under this agreement, UNEP-WCMC shall a) calculate statistics on the protected area coverage of the world’s terrestrial and marine ecological regions based on the 2011 version of the World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA) and b) prepare and publish the 2011 Protected Planet Report. The preparation and publication of the report will be co-funded by UNEP and the Finnish Government. The report will be launched at the CBD SBSTTA 15 meeting in Montreal and will measure progress made towards the CBD protected area targets.

Name: Mangroves W Africa REDD+
Memo:
This is a project through UNEP.
 
The Government of the Republic of Congo approached the United Nations Environment Programme in order to seek assistance in protecting the mangrove areas of  western central Africa (Gabon, Republic of Congo & DRC), as well as explorting the feasibility of setting up a REDD+ project for mangroves in the region. 
The objective is to conduct a study of the economic values of ecosystem services of the mangroves of the western central Africa region (encompassing Gabon, the Republic of Congo, and Democratic Republic of Congo) in order to inform the REDD+ processes in these countries and to make the case for the inclusion of mangrove forests in REDD+. The report should target the governments of the western central Africa area as well as the UNFCCC COP-17 in Durban in November/December 2011.
 
 
 
UNEP-WCMC's role would be to: 
1. improve baseline mangrove data through validation of the mangrove atlas data and possibly also an earlier time snapshot of data from Chandra Giri; 
2. develop baseline maps and statistics by country and a report on threats and pressures (at the country level) to mangroves. 
3. Possible third activity (TBD) would be to compile a spatial layer of C storage and sequestration indicators based on data collected by project partners. Gabriel Grimsditch is enquiring with UNREDD about the feasibility of adding this to the project.

Name: ICRI 2011
Memo: WCMC activity is focused on standardisation of coral reef layer attributes (working with Coral Health Index, Jerker, Gabriel & others), plus development of online validation tool in Ocean Data Viewer.

Name: Biodiversity criteria in IKI projects
Memo: The project will develop biodiversity criteria for integration into the guidelines for application, mid-term review and evaluation process of projects funded under the German International Climate Initiative (ICI, or IKI as of the German acronym). The overall aim is to make ICI projects more biodiversity relevant. Candidate criteria will be identified, discussed in expert group meetings and workshops with ICI project implementation partners, applied to projects, then refined and finalised.

Name: Case-studies for Petrobras
Comp Prog Name: UNEP-WCMC Business, Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services

Name: OSPAR Info System Needs Analysis
Memo: WCMC are working in partnership with the British Oceanographic Data Centre (BODC) to form a consultancy on specifications for an OSPAR information system. The purpose of the project is to prepare specifications which enable the OSPAR Commission to implement a reliable and sustainable information system, fully integrated and interoperable with other initiatives, to handle, assemble and display data, information and knowledge and to address external and internal communication and reporting needs.

Name: Ramsar RIS demo online tool
Memo: Preprare a demo version of a tool for on-line submiession of the Ramsar Site Information Sheet (RIS) in time for the pre-COP11 preparatory meetings and a live demo at COP11.

Name: Protected Planet Workshop and next steps
Memo: This project has three goals: 1) Bringing together a wide range of experts in a workshop to discuss priorities for further development of Protected Planet (workshop took place at UNEP-WCMC in May 2011); 2) Improving Protected Planet through the implementation of a number of the priorities identified at the workshop; and 3) Developing the first phase of the Protected Planet social networking features.

Name: ELAN EBA
Memo:
IUCN Support to the effectiveness of EBA  providing an Assessment Framework & Review of Case Studies
IIED, Birdlife International and UNEP-WCMC will deliver a framework for assessing existing evidence on ecosystem-based approaches to adaptation effectiveness, including guidance to apply the framework. They will also apply the framework to a selected number of EbA case studies.

Name: Nestle Biodiversity
Memo:
We’ve prepared a short proposal for the update of the sites based on Nestle new locations. We’ve presented 2 options, to run analysis for the 38 new sites and integrate this into the existing results, and to run the analysis for all sites, using more up-to-date data.  
 
In terms of writing up the methodology, we have the section of the report we wrote which lays out the way data were assessed which could be made a little more user friendly.
